Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/1/2024, youth and staff were involved in a physical
altercation. Youth threw a water bottle at staff which struck him in
the shoulder. In response, staff member pushed youth causing her
to fall over the back of a couch and hit the floor. As a result of the
incident youth has bruising on her left elbow and right hip.
Investigation This complaint was received on 04/03/2024 and assigned for joint
investigation with MDHHS Specialist.
Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 04/03/2024 and
reported they had no additional information.
I interviewed Consumer Rights Officer at the agency on
04/03/2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Consumer
Rights Officer reported he spoke with Staff 1 on 04/02/2024 after
reviewing the video footage of the incident. Staff 1 told Consumer
Rights Officer he was frustrated when Youth A threw the water
bottle at him, and he did not intend on pushing Youth A but was
trying to move her away from him. Consumer Rights Officer
reported Staff 1 has been put on administrative leave pending the
investigations. Youth A was examined by the Nurse on
04/02/2024. Youth A was provided pain medication and an ice
pack.
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 04/03/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A has been at the
agency for one month. Youth A reported she is struggling at the
agency due to conflict with the other girls. Youth A said staff are
always supervising and staff does intervene to prevent fights and
arguments with the other girls. Youth A reported on 04/01/2024
2

she was feeling very frustrated, but refused to say why she was
feeling frustrated. Youth A admitted she threw a water bottle at
Staff 1 and Staff 1 got up and pushed her over the bench. Youth A
said Staff 2 was in the room when this incident happened. Youth A
said she sustained a bruise on her lower back from being pushed
by Staff 1. Youth A lifted her shirt, and a light blue bruise was
observed on her lower back. Youth A said Staff 2 told her she
should not have thrown the bottle at Staff 1. Youth A was seen by
the nurse on 04/02/2024 and was provided with an ice pack and
pain medication.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker on 04/05/2024 via telephone.
Youth A has been at the agency since 02/15/2024. She said
Youth A is struggling due to her aggressive behavior. The agency
is addressing Youth A’s aggressive behavior in therapy. She
expressed no concerns for the agency prior to this incident.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the agency on 04/10/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 is a Youth Coach and has been
employed at the agency since 01/29/2024. Staff 1 reported on the
day of the incident Youth A was escalated and had been
struggling all afternoon. Earlier in the day Youth A wanted to call
her Foster Care Worker, which he attempted to contact, but the
worker did not answer her phone. Youth A continued to escalate,
hitting her head and attempting to hurt herself. Youth A pushed
and scratched Staff 1’s nose. He and Staff 2 were on the wing
with Youth A, and he continued to attempt to verbally de-escalate
Youth A. Youth A was still escalated and asked to go to the other
wing to see the other girls. He would not allow Youth A to go to
the other wing because Youth A was being verbally and physically
aggressive. Staff 1 said he did not react or engage with Youth A.
At one point he felt Youth A had calmed down and out of the blue
Youth A picked up a water bottle and threw it at him. Staff 1 said
at this point he was frustrated, got up, pushed Youth A away from
him, and left the wing. Staff 1 said he did not intend to hurt or
cause Youth A to fall. Staff 1 admitted he was very frustrated and
should have asked to be leave before the situation got out of
control.
I interviewed Staff 2 the agency on 04/10/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 is a Youth Coach and has been
working at the agency for one year. Staff 2 reported he witnessed
the incident between Staff 1 and Youth A. Staff 2 said Youth A
had been frustrated all day and was verbally and physically
lashing out on Staff 1. He said Staff 1 had been attempting to
verbally de-escalate Youth A, but Youth A calmed down for a few
3

minutes and then start acting out again. Staff 2 said he witnessed
Youth A throw a water bottle at Staff 1, Staff 1 got up and pushed
Youth A, resulting in Youth A falling backwards and hitting her
back on the bench. Staff 1 walked out of the unit and Staff 2
attempted to help Youth A. Staff 2 said he called for the
Supervisor to come unit.
I interviewed Supervisor at the agency on 04/10/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor reported she
was on another unit when the incident occurred between Staff 1
and Youth A. Supervisor said earlier in the day, she had asked
Staff 1 if he wanted to tap out after Youth A had scratched his
nose and Staff 1 said he was fine and did not want to tap out.
Supervisor was called to the wing after the incident. Youth A
reported to Supervisor that Staff 1 pushed her, and she fell
backwards over the bench.
A predisposition conference was held with MDHHS Specialist on
05/07//2024. There is a finding by MDHHS Specialist.
Video Review:
Video footage from 04/01/2024 was reviewed on 04/03/2024
(Note: video has no audio). Staff 1 is observed sitting on a chair,
Youth A is sitting on a bench across from Staff 1, and Staff 2
sitting approximately 5 feet across from Youth A. Youth A stood
up, stood over Staff 1, and threw a water bottle hitting Staff 1 in
the face. Staff 1 stood up, puts his hands on Youth A’s shoulder
and pushes her away from him, causing Youth A to fall
backwards, hitting her back against the bench, and falling on the
floor. Staff 1 leaves the room and Staff 2 tries to assist Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident report dated 04/01/2024 written by Staff 1. Incident
report is consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
• Medical assessment for Youth A dated 04/02/2024. Youth
A has a 3-inch blue in color bruise to her right hip area.
Youth A was provided with pain medication and an ice
pack.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: there was no disciplinary record for
Staff 1.
• Agency Policy: Staff and Client Interaction Guidelines for
staff and client interaction: All staff should conduct
themselves in a professional and appropriate manner when
interacting with the clients in our care. Employees are
expected to establish good working relationships to foster
mutual trust with clients. Corporal punishment (spanking,
4

paddling, slapping, pinching, twisting arms, pulling hair,
etc.) of clients is never, under any circumstances,
permitted.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per video footage
reviewed, staff and youth interviews confirm Staff 1 pushed Youth
A, which is an inappropriate and prohibited form of discipline.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
